g.text: improves the persistent luminescence intensity of BASO: Eu
but also decreases the persistent luminescence decay rate.
rare-earth ions are frequently non-luminescent. Instead, they
store energy as a trap center and gradually release the energy at
the function of temperature. They transmit the energy to the
luminescent center to generate persistent luminescence.
The intensity of persistent luminescence and the time of
duration are frequently decided by the existing state of the trap.
To research the generating process of the persistent
luminescence and the function of Tm
we test the three-dimensional thermoluminescence spectra of
axis represents the intensity of thermoluminescence.
plane is the thermoluminescence spectra of the sample
at diﬀerent temperatures and the persistent luminescence
emission spectra at one temperature. The
relationship curve of the temperature and emission intensity
monitoring at one temperature. Converting the three-dimen-
to the two-dimensional thermoluminescence curve about the
emission intensity and temperature using software, we obtain
b. We use thermoluminescence analysis software to
deal with the two-dimensional thermoluminescence curve of
parameters of thermoluminescence by software ﬁtting of the
curves. Because of the uncertainty of the thermoluminescence
dynamic series, the theory we use to ﬁt is based on the general
is the activated energy or the deepness of
is the density of charge captured in the trap when
= 0, which directly aﬀects the intensity of thermoluminescence,
shows the ﬁtting result of the sample
cence curve can be ﬁtted to break up into two thermolumi-
nescence peaks. The low-temperature peak is located at 326 K.
The corresponding trap deepness values are 0.62 and 0.70 eV.
If the peak position of thermoluminescence is too low, the
decay of persistent luminescence is very fast, and the time of
duration is short. If the peak position of thermoluminescence is
too high, the storage energy is diﬃcult to be released in room
temperature, and the persistent luminescence is weak. Thus,
the thermoluminescence peak position of the better persistent
luminescence material should be in the range of 320 and 393 K
There are two thermoluminescence peaks located at 326 and
thermoluminescence peaks both make contributions to the
persistent luminescence property of the sample. Also, the
thermoluminescence curve is a broad-band curve and can
cover the temperature region from 300 to 450 K. This
indicates that the distribution of traps in the material is wide.
Generally, it is believed that the release rate of energy in the
shallow trap is quick, the release rate of energy in the deep trap
is slow, and the duration time is long. From
see that the density of charge carrier captured in the shallow
trap and deep trap is basically close, which indicates that
possesses not only the high intensity
of persistent luminescence but also the long persistent
and 0.40). With the increase in Tm
intensity of persistent luminescence increases gradually. When
= 0.10, the thermoluminescence curve reaches the maximum.
nescence decreases with it. The possible reason may be the
concentration quenching owing to the excessive Tm
concentration. The storage energy returns to the ground
state in the form of non-radiative transitions. Besides, although
its persistent luminescence property is poor. The thermolumi-
